title: Q: Licences and third parties
body: What should you do to ensure data collected by third parties under contract can be made open?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Make sure that it is included as part of the contract
Not worry about it, as the third parties will handle that
Leave it to the legal department to sort out

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

To ensure that data collected by third parties can be made open, you need to make sure that it is included in the contract along with any terms that the government has about collecting, managing and storing that data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

To ensure that data collected by third parties can be made open, you need to make sure that it is included in the contract along with any terms that the government has about collecting, managing and storing that data.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Q: Barriers to success
body: Which of the following are common barriers to successful open data initiatives?
instruction: Choose your answer(s), then click 'Submit'

_items.text: No data available to publish
A fear of misusing data
A lack of willingness to share data with others
No suitable technology to make use of data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Cultural resistance and fear of data misuse are the most common barriers to achieving impact from data.

Technology and data are never in short supply.

The next section introduces the Open Data Institute's theory of change which looks at what needs to be done to overcome these barriers.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Cultural resistance and fear of data misuse are the most common barriers to achieving impact from data.

Technology and data are never in short supply.

The next section introduces the Open Data Institute's theory of change which looks at what needs to be done to overcome these barriers.

title: Q: Using standards in data
body: Which of the following might you see in a standard for data?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: How to consistently write numbers and dates
What abbreviations can be used
What file format the data should be available in
What data should be included
How much the data cost to produce

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Standards can be used for all sorts of things. For example:

  • to standardise the words that we use for concepts, classifications and individual words. For example, the definitions of different types of education across the UK.

  • to specify common formats and shared rules that lead to consistent data. For example, explaining what each of the headings in a CSV file means.

  • to help people and organisations understand how to collect, publish and use the data. For example, how to consistently record temperature readings.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Standards can be used for all sorts of things. For example:

  • to standardise the words that we use for concepts, classifications and individual words. For example, the definitions of different types of education across the UK.

  • to specify common formats and shared rules that lead to consistent data. For example, explaining what each of the headings in a CSV file means.

  • to help people and organisations understand how to collect, publish and use the data. For example, how to consistently record temperature readings.

title: Summary
body:
While transparency is a key pillar in an open government it is not the only area where open data can play a key role.

While current practices in some departments take a 'closed by default' approach, an 'open by default' approach would not only aid transparency but also provide benefits to the other pillars of an open government. 

Get yourself up to speed with the Open Data Strategy for Northern Ireland and take a look at our open data portal

title: Summary
body:
Open data has the power to help drive innovation, transform societies and protect our planet.

Open data can help governments grow economies, improve service delivery and save costs.

Open data can benefit society by reducing wasted time and money from travel times, business friction and excess spending.

Open data can help save lives and help us better understand the world in which we live.

Want more local examples of open data? You can find more stories on the OpenDataNI Showcase and Detail Data’s Data Stories and follow @opendatani on Twitter.

Want to increase your data literacy? Carry on with these modules. In the next module, we explore how to engage in an open data initiative.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Summary
body:
Open data initiatives often require culture change, which can be hard work.

Your open data initiative is much more likely to success if it:

  • has strong, visible leadership
  • actively engages with users
  • considers where the demand is and focuses on that instead of publishing everything at once
  • can help others overcome their inclination to hoard or fear data

then it is much more likely to succeed.

Read more about the Open Data Institute's theory of change to create positive impact from data.

Need help with your open data initiative? Find out who your departmental representative on the Open Government Action Group is, and get in touch for their support.

In the next module, we'll look at simplifying open data licences.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Summary
body:
Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it. Both of these require the permission of the publisher, granted via an open licence. However, the open licence alone is not sufficient to guarantee the usability of data. 

There are legal, practical, technical and social requirements and guidelines that publishers can use to make their data more usable. 

Quality marques such as the 5 Star Linked Open Data system and the Open Data Certificates inform users that the data is a certain quality.

The FAIR data principles, making sure that data is findable, accessible, interoperable and reusable, helps to make it easier for people to access, use and share.

Standards for data help to make data more reusable and easier to combine with other data. The Open Standards for Data guidebook has lots of information including the impact of using standards, how to choose an open standard to apply to your data, and who is already using open standards for data.

title: Marques of quality
body:
Marques of quality provide users with confidence about the quality and usability of open data.

There are two key indicators of open data quality:
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: 5 Stars
_items.body: The 5 Star Linked Open Data system was developed by inventor of the Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, in 2010, and makes recommendations for the legal and technical requirements of linked data. All the data published on Open Data NI should be 3 stars. You can find out more about the 5 stars in Module 10 of this course.

_items.title: ODI Open Data Certificates
_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificates complement the legal and technical requirements included in the 5 stars Linked Open Data system. Certificates have been designed to cover the broadest range of both technical and non-technical requirements that increase usability of data. Each section – legal, practical, technical and social – expands in more detail from the general points covered in this module.

The certificates act as a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers and awards kite marks at different levels as well as recommendations on how to reach the next level of usability.

title: Summary
body:
When comparing and measuring open data initiatives, it is important to use a broad framework and focus on demand.

These methods help your initiative to stay on track and emulate the success of other open data initiatives.

KPIs also help drive the changes that organisations require to participate effectively in the open data community.

In the next module, we explore how to find sustainable sources of open data.

title: Summary
body:
When searching for sustainable sources of open data, it is important that they are relevant, up-to-date and accessible.

A sustainable programme is one that continues to release data regularly, with at least the same or improving quality and quantity.

Using simple indicators listed above, it is possible to identify sustainable sources of open data that can be used in your future work.

In the next module, we explore how open data platforms can simplify the process of publishing and using data.

title: Summary
body:
Open data platforms are pieces of software that make it simpler to publish and manage open data on the Web.

For publishers, an open data platform provides a pathway to publish data, guiding them through the process. We use Open Data NI which is run on CKAN to publish all NI government open data.

For users, platforms can help make open data from around the world consistent and easy to access.

To find out how easy it is to publish open data on OpenDataNI, check out our Publisher Demos Playlist on YouTube.

title: Open data platforms across Europe
body: Europe is home to hundreds of open data platforms at the local, regional and national level. When searching for open data, it can be useful to access a directory of these platforms to help you locate what sources of data are available. The OpenDataMonitor project is a European index of open data sites and provides a useful reference guide. Why not explore the index to discover what data is available for different countries, regions and cities?

title: Summary
body:
Assessing how useful data is can vary widely depending on the domain and the specific content. To help with this process there are a number of guidelines, including the 5 Star LInked Open Linked Data system.
The5 Star Linked Open Data system is a way to measure how well data is integrated into the web. Each star must be awarded sequentially and none can be skipped.

All data published on OpenDataNI should be to 3 star standard. If you need help, get in touch with us at opendata@finance-ni.gov.uk

title: The 5 Star Linked Open Data system
displayTitle: The 5 Star Linked Open Data system
body:
The 5 Star Linked Open Data system is a way to measure how well data is integrated into the web.

It examines the accessibility and technical usability of a dataset ranging from being available online (1 star) to being part of the web of data (5 stars). Each star must be awarded sequentially and none can be skipped.

The guidelines were developed by Sir Tim Berners-Lee in 2010 and have been adopted by publishers worldwide to help guide many open data initiatives, including OpenDataNI.

Every dataset published on OpenDataNI should be of 3 star standard. In this module, we explore how to do that.

title: The first 3 stars
body: Publishing data that meets 3 stars means that the data is reusable.
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: 1 star - Open licence
_items.body:
The first star is awarded to any data that is open at a basic level. The content, in any format, must be available under an open licence.

Regardless of the quality of a dataset, it cannot qualify for the first star unless it is available under an open licence.

A PDF file on a website available under an open licence is enough to fulfil the first star.

_items.title: 2 star - Re-usable format
_items.body:
The second star is awarded to any data that allows for simple re-use. The guidelines state that the data must be available in a ‘highly-reusable, structured format’ that can be read by a machine and understood by a human.

The key to achieving 2 stars is to select the most re-usable format. In some cases, the most re-usable format may be a closed or proprietary one, such as an Excel or Numbers file.

Making data available in any format is better than none at all.

_items.title: 3 star - Open format
_items.body:
The guidelines for the third star of open data state that the data must be available in a structured, machine-readable format which is not tied to a specific software package.

An example of a dataset that would be awarded 3 stars is a CSV file with an appropriate open licence, such as this example on OpenDataNI.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Our measures of success
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.

_items.title: Activity on OpenDataNI
_items.body:
We will have succeeded when we can demonstrate sustained increase in the quantity of open data available on the portal. Having data available is essential for our open data strategy and links directly to the Barometer’s implementation indicator.

Another measure of success is a wide range of use cases in our Showcase. This is to demonstrate what impact we are having.

_items.title: Culture change across NI gov and NICS
_items.body:
We will have succeeded when we have a culture of proactive publishing across the Northern Irish Civil Service and that we have embedded an ‘Open by Default’ agenda.

When internal staff can articulate the benefits and potential of open data, we know that we will have succeeded.

Both of these success measures link to the Barometer’s readiness indicator.

_items.title: Automated processes
_items.body:
We will have succeeded when we have data validation tools to ensure better quality data. Using these tools will be simple and quick, where a machine does most of the work to improve the accuracy, consistency and cleanliness of the data.

In addition, we will have succeeded when we are able to use automated publication pipelines, meaning that the process is quick and efficient for staff, while ensuring the timely publication of open data.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Summary
body:
The format of an open dataset refers to the way in which the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right structure and format helps ensure the data can be simply managed and reused. To maximise reuse of the data, it may be necessary for a publisher to use a number of structures and formats available across different platforms to suit users' needs.

Wherever possible, the CSV file format should be used for sharing open data. CSV is a simple to understand, highly reusable and machine readable format.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]
Open Data NI [All rights reserved]
The Open Data Institute [CC0]
The Open Data Institute [CC0]

title: How useful is my data?
body:
Assessing how useful open data is can vary depending on the domain and the content. To assist this process, there are a number of best practice guidelines publishers and users can follow.

In this module, we look at the 5 Star Linked Open Data system and discover how this can be used to measure the technical usability of data.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What is the 5 Star Linked Open Data system
  • The first 3 Stars
  • How to recognise the stars in data

title: Summary
body:
For data to be open, it should be licensed for anyone to access, use and share. Licensing gives permission to businesses, startups, governments and individuals to innovate with your open data. 

People working for Crown bodies in the UK are mandated to use the OGL when publishing open data. UK Government Licensing Framework is a resource to start using the OGL.

Open data licensing should be provided for in the tendering, procurement and contracting lifecycle.

In the next module, we assess open data quality and look at how easy it is to prepare data for users to use.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY]

title: Summary
body:
Data cleaning is essential to ensure that when the data is used, the right conclusions are made.

Often errors are not even noticed by data publishers because the data can change over many years. Errors can be the result of human mistakes in data entry, like mistyping or incorrect abbreviations.

Be aware that cleaning may take longer than you think. A careful cleaning process will, however, save substantial time in the long run.

Watch this introductory video to Open Refine (previously Google Refine) and follow our data cleaning exercise to get started with Open Refine and discover how easy it is for yourself.

title: The pillars of open government
body: Open government is made up of three key pillars: transparency, participation and accountability. Although not an official pillar, innovation is essential for an open government to deliver its commitments, which is why it’s included here.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Transparency
_items.body:
Transparency of information is the foundation of accountability in public services and open government.

Francis Maude, former minister for the Cabinet Office with responsibility for public transparency and open data said: "Transparency shines a light on underperformance and inefficiencies in public services. It allows citizens and the media to hold governments to account, strengthening civil society and building more open societies."

The UK and devolved nations have individual commitments to Open Government.  Transparency is an essential part of Northern Ireland’s ongoing commitments, including improving transparency of government contracting, opening government and property data and building trust in government services.

_items.title: Participation
_items.body:
An open government should encourage an independent civil society by involving people and organisations in developing, monitoring and evaluating government activities.

Freedom of information provides a channel for the public to request information from public authorities. WhatDoTheyKnow is a UK site that helps people make freedom of information requests, and publishes all requests and responses online, reducing the duplicate requests and making information available to anyone.

Both the UK as a whole and the devolved nations have Open Government Networks. These are alliances between individual people, activists and representatives of community and voluntary organisations to get more voices heard and make government more open, transparent and accountable.

_items.title: Accountability
_items.body:
An open government should put in place mechanisms and laws so they can be held to account.

These include commitments to: publish information on the income and assets of high-ranking public officials; expose corrupt bidders; implement open contracting data standards; recover stolen assets; and protect whistleblowers.

Increasingly, countries are taking steps to publish ‘beneficial ownership’ data – that is, information about who really owns and controls companies. This is important for exposing corruption, fraud, organised crime and tax evasion. 

Anti-corruption and accountability efforts are not just important in the UK but for any country that the UK chooses to do business with.

_items.title: Innovation
_items.body:
Technology has had a profound effect on all aspects of our lives. It has changed the way governments deliver services and engage with people 

As a result people now expect to be able to engage through advanced digital platforms that deliver end-to-end services across government departments, from applying for benefits and passports, to paying parking fines and getting information on waste collection.

Governments have a key role to play in both delivering and enabling others to build digital services and technological innovation

title: What is open government?
body:
The UK is one of eight cofounding members of the Open Government Partnership (OGP), an initiative set up in 2011 and now signed by over 75 countries around the world. The OGP is an international platform for reformers committed to making their governments more open, accountable and responsive to people.

You can explore what the different country members are currently working on to improve openness in government.

Despite being a founding member, the OGP has recently raised concerns about the UK’s ability to adhere to the pillars of open government, meaning that there is a lot more work to be done.

title: Q: What are the pillars of open government?
displayTitle: What are the pillars of open government?
body: The pillars of open government are...
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Transparency, participation and accountability
Finance, education and health
Freedom of information, service delivery and innovation

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open government consists of transparency, participation and accountability.

Engagement, freedom of information and the publication of open data are all key activities that fit into the work of open government.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open government consists of transparency, participation and accountability.

Engagement, freedom of information and the publication of open data are all key activities that fit into the work of open government.

title: Open government and open data
body:
The Northern Ireland Executive has committed to an ambitious agenda on open data and transparency in government to improve the day-to-day lives of people in Northern Ireland.

Improved open data can help the public to make more informed decisions and the public sector to deliver better services. It can improve policymaking, stimulate economic growth and improve our environment.

In this module, we are going to explore...

  • What is open government?
  • What is open data?
  • What is the role of open data in an open government?
  • Moving to an open by default agenda

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]

title: Q: What makes data open?
body: Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Open data must...
instruction: Choose your answer(s), then click 'Submit'

_items.text: be free from restrictions for its use
be restricted in its use
be selectively released for a fee
have a licence
not have a licence

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data must be licensed so that users know that they are allowed to use and share the data.

For anyone to use the data it must be free of restrictions for its use. If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data must be licensed so that users know that they are allowed to use and share the data.

For anyone to use the data it must be free of restrictions for its use. If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as open data.

title: What makes data open?
body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness:
instruction: Click the headings to explore further

_items.title: Licence
_items.body:
Open data must be free from restrictions and openly licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.

For data to be open, it should have no restrictions that prevent it from being used in any particular way.

Anyone should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data, even commercially.

_items.title: Cost
_items.body: Government open data must be free to access. There is often a cost to creating, maintaining and publishing usable data which is already paid by the taxpayer.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use, reuse and redistribute it – even commercially.

Open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format. Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, but these do not make the data more open.

title: What is data?
body: At the heart of open government is open data. First let us consider what we mean by data.
instruction: Click the headings to explore further

_items.title: Data
_items.body: Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be applied. Data is often presented as figures in spreadsheets, though this isn’t the only format for data.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Information is what happens when someone uses data to create a graph, chart or dashboard. Presenting information like this is useful to understand patterns or trends in data, but it doesn’t allow anyone to do their own analysis, or to check that what is being said is correct. If you create information from data, consider linking the data alongside if you can.

A clear example of information without data is Where Your Money Goes, a dashboard showing the Irish Government’s Expenditure data. It would be even more useful, if it included the data that powers the dashboard.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body: Knowledge is what happens when you turn data and information into choice, such as policy decisions that are based on data and information.

title: Q: Open by default
body:
Many governments are moving to an open by default agenda.

What does open by default mean?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Data that is not legally or ethically sensitive should be automatically open
All data should be automatically available for anyone to use, including personal data
If data is demanded over a petition with over 100,000 signatures then it must be made open

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open by default is the principle that data should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal or ethical reason why it should remain closed.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open by default is the principle that data should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal or ethical reason why it should remain closed.

title: Being open by default
body:
Open by default is the principle that data should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal or ethical reason why it should remain closed. This principle is at the heart of an open government and the first principle of the G8 Open Data Charter and the Open Data Strategy for Northern Ireland.

This represents a complete mind change for many who currently take a demand-led approach to the publication of open data. That doesn’t mean that taking a demand-led approach is wrong, as success stories and examples of impact can help unlock budgets and gather buy-in for publishing more data openly. Think of it as a stepping stone on the way to an open by default agenda.

The Canadian government is piloting an open by default approach to releasing public sector information in four of its departments. The pilot promotes the proactive release of scientific and cultural research data which supports government transparency and accountability.

The Northern Ireland Executive is working to embed open data into ‘business as usual’ across the Northern Ireland Civil Service and the wider NI public sector.

title: What is the role of open data in an open government?
displayTitle: What is the role of open data in an open government?
body: Open data helps to deliver all the pillars of an open government.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Transparency
_items.body:
Traditionally, the main purpose of the freedom of information legislation is to ensure transparency: the principle is that people have a right to know about the activities of public authorities, unless there is a good reason for them not to.

However, pro-active publication of open data has the potential to deliver much wider benefits and encourage better public engagement. It can both reduce the number of freedom of information requests and streamline the response to others. 

In Carlisle, the publication of real-time business rates has reduced the number of freedom of information requests, saving the council up to £15,000 annually. Read the report here [PDF]: Local Government Open Data Breakthrough Projects Evaluation Report 2014/15.

Open data can help make governments more transparent. It can provide evidence that public money is being well spent and policies are being implemented.

For example, openly publishing procurement data ensures value for money, public integrity and helps track spending and service delivery. Openly publishing five more pieces of information about each contracting tender would save European governments up to €3.6 billion.

_items.title: Participation
_items.body:
Open data allows people to see inside the workings of government, to monitor service delivery, hold government agencies to account and participate in decision making.

The city of Gijón in Northern Spain has Participa Gijón (Participate in Gijón), a platform that people can use to engage with decision makers to negotiate, shape the development agenda and improve public service. New regulations, city plans and competitions are open for public debate. One of the biggest collaborative decisions made via Participa Gijón has been how best to spend the city of Gijon’s 2017 €6 million participative budget, and then the data is made open.

_items.title: Accountability
_items.body:
In 2016 the UK became the first country in the world to collect and publish, in a structured format, data about who controls and benefits from companies.

Another way the UK government is making sure it can be held to account is by publishing open data on government grant spending. In October 2017, the government introduced a platform allowing departments to share information on £100 billion worth of grants data from across government departments using a standard format developed by 360Giving.

Making contracting and procurement more transparent can also have big impact. For example Paraguay is using open contracting to improve spending on education. Information about education contracts unearthed a wider spending scandal that triggered a formal investigation, public pressure and reform of school spending. You can read many more stories about open contracting data from the Open Contracting Partnership.

_items.title: Innovation
_items.body:
Open data can help deliver new services to the public while driving efficiencies in the delivery of current public services.

Many governments run open data innovation funds to work with developers and innovators to solve specific problems.

Belfast City Council is reaping the benefits of running an open data innovation fund, thanks to the Small Business Research Initiative. Using the Food Standards Agency Rating ‘Scores on the Doors’ and Companies House, the council has been able to identify business premises that weren’t paying business rates, Rectifying this has given Belfast City Council an additional £500,000 in previously uncollected business rates in the pilot phase alone.

title: Q: Opportunities for government
body: Open data creates many opportunities for local and national governments. Which of the following are the benefits of open data for governments?
instruction: Choose an answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Building new services, while making existing services better
Saving money and improving efficiency
Increasing transparency and strengthening civic participation
Getting donations

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data helps governments to deliver new and improved services, be more efficient and save time and money, and increase transparency and civic participation.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data helps governments to deliver new and improved services, be more efficient and save time and money, and increase transparency and civic participation.

title: Opportunities for government
body: The public sector benefits from open data initiatives in many ways:
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Supporting growing economies
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, governments need to publish key datasets.

In 2019, the open data market size in the EU27 (excluding the UK) was worth nearly €185 billion, with over a million people employed as a result of open data. The UK’s open data market exceeded €30 billion, or £26 billion in the same year.

In 2025, the EU’s open data market size is predicted to grow to between €2 billion and €3.3 billion, with the creation of an additional 100–950 million jobs.

Find out more about the Economic Impact of Open Data.

_items.title: Improved service delivery
_items.body:
Governments need to balance the demands of growing populations with the need to tackle small-scale, local issues.

The availability of detailed open data is essential to improving the delivery of services at the local level.

FixMyStreet makes it easier for people to report problems in the community, even if they don’t know who to report the problems to.

People in Leeds can get weekly reminders of when their bins are due to be collected. This is more convenient for people, and publishing this open data electronically instead of sending letters also saves the council approximately £100,000 per year. The council then uses open data about the use of the app to target communications about household waste.

_items.title: Cost savings
_items.body:
Open data helps governments to reduce costs in key areas.

Duplicate efforts cost governments millions. In 15 minutes, one UK government minister discovered how to save £4 million, when open spending data allowed him to find duplicate transactions.

In a similar story, open data identified £194 million of savings over 7 years in the Northern Ireland health service that could be made if GPs prescribed generic rather than branded medication.

Local councils are also saving costs. In Carlisle, publishing real-time business rates significantly reduced the number of Freedom of Information requests, improving the process for local businesses and saving the council up to £15,000 per year.

title: Innovation and growth in businesses
body:
Open data is supporting innovation and growth by revealing opportunities for businesses to build new services, identify savings and improve operations.

SpendNetwork pulls together open spending, contract and tender data to provide insight and consultancy services.

GreenCitySolutions have built the CityTree which helps purify air from pollutants and adds greenery to urban areas. The company uses open data to help assess the effectiveness and efficiency of their trees.

Exceedance is an Irish startup that provides financial analytics softwares for customers to compare the cost and impact of renewable technologies and projects. 

The Open Data Incubator for Europe (ODINE) supports startups and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that build sustainable businesses around open data.

Existing businesses can expand their offering thanks to data. Real Estate company Zoopla uses open mapping, transport and local area data to make it easy for potential buyers to compare properties and local areas. Credit score company Experian uses open data to improve its affordability checks and assessments.

Open data stimulates innovation by removing barriers to access, use and shareability of data.

title: Q: Innovation and growth in businesses
body: Open data supports innovation and growth. Which of these are real services built on open data?
instruction: Choose an answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Improving air quality in and around cities
Providing business-to-business services built on open procurement data
Helping consumers buy into renewable energies

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

These are all real services that are built on open data. Read on to find out more about them.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

These are all real services that are built on open data. Read on to find out more about them.

title: Q: Impact on society
body:
Open data is unlocking new social value in the way we travel, work and spend money.

Which of the following applications or services have you used?
instruction: Choose all that you've used, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Mapping apps such as Google Maps
Transport apps such as CityMapper or Translink Journey Planner
Music apps such as Spotify
Credit score companies like Experian
Wikipedia

_feedback.correct: Many apps and services are already using open data without advertising it to their customers. All the above applications and sites use open data to enrich their services and add value for their customers.

_incorrect.final: Many apps and services are already using open data without advertising it to their customers. All the above applications and sites use open data to enrich their services and add value for their customers.

title: Q: Impact on society
body: You have already been using services that rely on open data for your benefit, think about what other benefits opening up government data could bring to people including yourself.
instruction: Click the headings to explore further

_items.title: Reducing travel times
_items.body:
Open data has the power to revolutionise the way we travel. From tech giants to startups across the world, open data is making it easier for people to travel from A to B.

Google, Apple, Moovit, Citymapper and Wayze among others, all use open transport data on traffic, buses, trains, bike-sharing systems and more to save commuters time, make journeys more accessible and help tourists to travel in unfamiliar cities.

Over 42% of Londoners use an app powered by Transport for London’s (TfL's) open data. It’s estimated that TfL’s open data generates annual economic benefits and savings of up to £130 million for travellers, London and TfL itself.

Open data also helps with greener travel. In many cities, including Belfast, open data is helping cyclists to find the nearest available bike stand.

_items.title: Reducing business friction
_items.body:
Open data is changing the way we work.

Open data reduces the time needed to find information and allows professionals to focus more of their time on productive activities.

OpenCorporates offers an open database of companies around the world, showing their networks, financial stability and environmental impact. This helps organisations learn more about prospective clients, providers and partners.

Thomson Reuters offers a variety of data services on finance, risk, information on companies and news stories. With data existing across a variety of services, Thomson Reuters turned to open data to link up their data services while avoiding complex rights issues in data. By openly publishing identifiers, staff, clients and external organisations were able to connect, link and share vast amounts of business intelligence data.

_items.title: Reducing spending waste
_items.body:
Open data helps consumers to make more informed choices.

In New South Wales, Australia, motorists can save up to 40 cents per gallon on fuel, thanks to open data.

Using Open Food Facts, consumers worldwide can scan food product barcodes to compare the carbon footprints, nutritional value and recyclability of different products. Much like Wikipedia, anyone can add missing products to the database.

title: Benefiting culture and the environment
body: Open data is helping us make better decisions for our planet and the people on it.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: Public health
_items.body:
Open data can benefit the health and wellbeing of people across the planet.

Across England, open data is making it easier for people to get active by finding details of physical activities happening in their area.

The Covid-19 pandemic has highlighted the importance of being open with data. Local and national governments publish and use open data on the spread of Covid-19 to help track the cases, make targeted efforts to control the spread and inform policy decisions.

Take me to the UK’s Covid-19 dashboard

_items.title: The environment
_items.body:
Open data benefits the environment in many ways.

Open data-based applications can serve as a tool to help households reduce their energy consumption by providing them with reports and suggestions on how to decrease energy usage. In these reports, open aggregated energy consumption data is combined with household energy data (which is not open).

Open data is helping to reduce overfishing in our oceans. Over one third (34%) of the world’s major commercial fish species are currently overfished. Global Fishing Watch tracks the location of commercial fishing vessels and works with governments to prosecute people engaging in illegal fishing activities.

Open data helps farmers to improve yields and support a growing population without the need to destroy valuable habitats. Plantwise is collecting open data to produce valuable information packs for farmers about plant health and threats from diseases.

_items.title: In an emergency
_items.body:
Open data is helping to save lives in an emergency.

Real time traffic data based on open data helps ambulances across Europe get to the incident faster. Saving one minute per ride could save up to 100,000 lives per year.

Open geographic data and aid statistics are being used by humanitarian groups to deliver targeted supplies in disaster zones.

Open mapping data helps disaster response teams target aid delivery during earthquakes, typhoons and hurricanes. The first major open mapping initiative from the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team was in response to the 2010 Haiti Earthquake, and open mapping data has been used for disaster relief ever since.

title: Active engagement
body:
Whilst active leadership delivers a 'push' from the organisation, active dialogue creates a 'pull' from data users. Engagement with civil society, business and governments are key aspects of any open data initiative.

Successful initiatives tend to start with an open dialogue between open data publishers and consumers. Remember that consumers can also be within governments, sometimes from the same department.

When thinking about what to publish, consider:
instruction: Click the headings to explore further

_items.title: Your approach
_items.body:
Some open data publishers take an open by default approach. Open by default is the first principle of the Open Data Strategy for Northern Ireland and means that data should automatically be open for everyone to access, use and share unless there is a legal or ethical reason why it should remain closed. 

While the open by default approach provides the basis for making data open, where to start can often be overwhelming. For publishers at the beginning of their open data journey, starting to think about the needs of data consumers can help you shape your initiative accordingly. Responding to needs can generate quick success stories and examples of impact which can help to secure more support for publishing more open data.

A staged approach helps to ensure that an organisation can walk before it tries to run, and achieves change in small, noticeable steps, rather than setting ambitious goals that are hard to meet.

_items.title: Who wants your data?
_items.body:
It is often best to focus on demand that currently exists so that you can quickly generate lots of use cases. Use existing consumer dialogues, opinion surveys or ‘vox pops’ to see where the demand is, and follow it. Don’t forget that a lot of demand will come from within governments as well as outside.

Think about problems that already exist and how the data relates to them. Frame the data as a tool to help build solutions.

A successful open data initiative has an engaged community who actively use the data, with access to resources that support them. An example of a strong open data community is the Open Street Map project. The community has a strong sense of ownership over the data itself and the outputs generated from it.

_items.title: How can you encourage reuse of data?
_items.body:
Consider the channels that you have to engage with data users. Do you use social media or web presence? Are there events to celebrate data publication and reuse? Are there cross-government channels to encourage internal reuse?

OpenDataNI includes discussion forums. Replying quickly to users’ questions and fostering an active community will encourage data reuse.

Encourage reuses by promoting showcases and case studies around data. If you know of someone who is using open data from your department, encourage them to share it on OpenDataNI’s Showcase and share on social media.

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]

title: Open data: agent of change
body:
The most successful open data initiatives share similar characteristics. Understanding successful approaches can help unlock the value of open data.

In this module we’ll explore:

  • Open data as an agent of change
  • Active leadership
  • Active engagement
  • Culture change

title: Engaging in open data initiatives - in two minutes
displayTitle: Engaging in open data initiatives - in two minutes
body: ODI International Development Manager Liz Carolan shares five characteristics of successful open data initiatives.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: Q: Open data as an agent of change
displayTitle: Open data as an agent of change
body:
Implementing an open data initiative often involves cultural and institutional change.

Opening data goes far beyond putting data on a website under an open licence. Applying the technology is the easy part – bringing about cultural change can be much harder.

So what helps make an open data initiative successful?
instruction: Choose your answer(s), then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Strong, active leadership
Engaging with users
Focus on cultural, not technical, change
Focus on impact
A staged approach
Giving it all to the IT department to deal with

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Successful open data initiatives have strong leadership to help gather institutional buy-in. They identify where the demand is for open data and engage with the community at all stages. Successful open data initiatives focus on the impact they are trying to achieve, and use a staged approach rather than publish everything at once.

The technology is the easy part; it’s the cultural change that can be much harder.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Successful open data initiatives have strong leadership to help gather institutional buy-in. They identify where the demand is for open data and engage with the community at all stages. Successful open data initiatives focus on the impact they are trying to achieve, and use a staged approach rather than publish everything at once.

The technology is the easy part; it’s the cultural change that can be much harder.

title: Active leadership
body:
Active leadership helps foster successful open data initiatives and bring about positive change.

As an open data programme is launched, it’s common to meet resistance from inside the organisation. Open data presents a huge cultural change for some, who may not feel ready for it.

Visible support from senior figures can help to encourage institutional buy-in. Having a strong leader who can clearly articulate their vision and lead by example goes a long way to encourage others to accept and sometimes embrace the change.

title: Common barriers: Hoarding data
body:
One of the biggest challenges to successful and impactful open data programmes is the lack of cultural willingness to share data. This scenario is known as ‘the oil field’.

The oil field is a scenario where owning as much data as possible and keeping it in one place limits its value. It’s called the oil field, because data is treated like oil. Its value is only realised by a few organisations and there are side-effects from its use that affect society as a whole.

Such approaches lead to a closed (or walled garden) environment which can greatly reduce innovation capabilities.

To overcome this barrier, organisations should support an open culture as much as possible. During challenging times it is especially important to realise the benefits of working with others, sharing insights and innovating together.

title: Unlocking value from open data – in three minutes
displayTitle: Unlocking value from open data – in three minutes
body:
Data literacy is essential for businesses looking to take advantage of the opportunities open data offers to create new value and improve operations.

ODI Trainer Ben Cave examines how businesses and governments need to be data literate in order to unlock  value from open data and the positive impacts this has on the economy, society and the environment.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: New Component Title
body:
"We need people who can work with data, drive the tools, write code and manipulate the data. But we also need people to be able to critique the use of data, understand its constraints and its impact on society. We need this blend of skills to get the best out of data."

 Dr Jeni Tennison, ODI Vice President – ODI Summit 2020

title: Unlocking value from open data
body:
Open data has the potential to help grow economies, transform societies and protect the environment.

In this module, we explore how governments, businesses and individuals are using open data to create new value.

In this module we’ll explore:

  • Opportunities for governments
  • Innovation and growth in businesses
  • Impact on society and public policy
  • Benefits for culture and the environment
  • How data literacy can help unlock value

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]
The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: The Open Government Licence (OGL)
body:
The UK Government uses the Open Government Licence (OGL). It is mandatory for Crown bodies and recommended for use by other public sector bodies.

The UK’s open data portal, data.gov.uk, and Northern Ireland’s open data portal, OpenDataNI, use the OGL.

This example from Open Data NI clearly shows the licence on the left side, where the dataset is accessed. The licence information is a hyperlink that displays the licence in full.

You may also find the UK Government Licensing Framework useful. It provides a policy and legal overview for licensing in the UK public sector.

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]

title: Why do we need to license?
displayTitle: Why do we need to license?
body:
For data to be open, it should be accessible (this usually means being published online) and licensed for anyone to access, use and share.

In this module we'll explore:

  • Why open data needs to be licensed
  • What type of licence suits open data
  • How to provide for open data licensing in the tender, procurement and contracting lifecycle

Even in cases where data has been made available as a public domain dedication without conditions on reuse, an explicit statement is required together with the data to provide users with legal clarity.

title: Simplifying open data licences – in two minutes
displayTitle: Simplifying open data licences – in two minutes
body: ODI Policy Lead Ellen Broad explains why we need open data licences, how they help unlock the value of data and best practice in choosing the right type of licence.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: Q: What do we need to license?
displayTitle: Why do we need to license?
body: Why does open data need to have a licence?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Data without a licence is not open
Users may prefer not to use the data as they don’t know if there are any restrictions in its use
Data without a licence might be subject to copyright
Users know who to pay for its use
Data without a licence can’t be charged for

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Without a licence, data is not truly open.

A licence tells anyone that they can access, use and share data.

Unless you have a licence, data may be ‘publicly available', but users will not have permission to access, use and share it under copyright or database laws.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Without a licence, data is not truly open.

A licence tells anyone that they can access, use and share data.

Unless you have a licence, data may be ‘publicly available', but users will not have permission to access, use and share it under copyright or database laws.

title: Why license open data?
body:
An open data licence provides users with certainty that the data can be used and shared for a wide range of purposes, including for commercial purposes.

Without a licence, data is not truly open.

A licence tells anyone that they can access, use and share data.

Unless you have a licence, data may be ‘publicly available’, but users will not have permission to access, use and share it under copyright or database laws.

title: Q: Understanding the OGL
body: See if you can sort the following conditions into the three boxes to replicate the OGL.

_items.text: Attribute the data provider
Use for commercial purposes
Use for non commercial purposes
Claim endorsement for the work
Adapt the data

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The Open Government Licence provides users with certainty that the data can be accessed, used, modified and shared for a wide range of purposes, even commercially.

Those who use data licensed under the OGL must attribute the data provider.

A data user cannot claim ownership, endorsement or any damages from the data publisher that result from their use or analysis of the data, regardless of the quality of the data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The Open Government Licence provides users with certainty that the data can be accessed, used, modified and shared for a wide range of purposes, even commercially.

Those who use data licensed under the OGL must attribute the data provider.

A data user cannot claim ownership, endorsement or any damages from the data publisher that result from their use or analysis of the data, regardless of the quality of the data.

title: Understanding the OGL
body:
The best licences are easy to understand, compatible with widely used licences and easy to comply with. The OGL was designed in this way.

The best licences also make it clear:

  • what users can do with the data

  • what the users must do if they use the data

  • what (if anything) the users can’t do with the data

title: Q: Other open licences
body:
In the UK, the OGL is mandatory for Crown bodies and recommended for use by other public sector bodies.

However, there are other types of licences, which you may come across when looking for data to access, use or share. 

What licence does Ireland’s open data portal use?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Creative Commons Attribution
Creative Commons Attribution & Share Alike
The UK Open Government Licence
Its own bespoke licence

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data.gov.ie uses the Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY 4.0), which is one of the most widely used licences for open content. CC-BY 4.0 is equivalent and compatible with the UK OGL. This means you can remix and combine data available under both licences without risk of legal issues relating to incompatible licences.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Data.gov.ie uses the Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY 4.0), which is one of the most widely used licences for open content. CC-BY 4.0 is equivalent and compatible with the UK OGL. This means you can remix and combine data available under both licences without risk of legal issues relating to incompatible licences.

title: Creative Commons licences
body:
Creative Commons marks and licences are widely used for open content. Version 4.0 explicitly considers data licensing. You can choose a licence (or mark) that works for you at the Creative Commons website. 

There are three Creative Commons marks and licences that are open:

_items.title: Public domain: (CC0)
_items.body: The public domain mark can be used by a copyright holder to waive all your rights over a piece of data, including copyright. This is particularly useful in the sharing of data and databases, since it otherwise may be unclear whether highly factual data and databases are restricted by copyright or other rights.

_items.title: Attribution: (CC-BY v4.0)
_items.body:
The Creative Commons attribution licence gives users rights to access, use and share (even commercially) your content. The only restriction is that the user must give credit to the data publisher (rights holder).

The Irish government has adopted CC-BY v4.0 for data.gov.ie.  CC-BY 4.0 is equivalent and compatible with the UK OGL. This means you can remix and combine data available under both licences without risk of legal issues relating to incompatible licences.

_items.title: Attribution and Share-Alike (CC-BY-SA v4.0)
_items.body: The Creative Commons attribution and share-alike licence is the same as the attribution license with the added restriction that the data user must share back any changes and modifications made to the data.

title: Q: Bespoke/Custom-made licences
body:
A bespoke or custom-made licence is created by the data publisher and introduces specific conditions with which the user must comply. Bespoke or custom-made licences can be written by the publisher or adapted from a standard licence through the addition of new conditions and/or the modification of existing ones.

Bespoke and custom-made licences can increase complexity for users of open data.

They may introduce specific conditions that limit usage, restrict data integration and, in some cases, are difficult for users to comply with.

If you come across a bespoke licence for data, what clauses will tell you if it is open?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: You can use the data for any purpose, even commercially
You can use the data for non-commercial or research purposes only
You can use the data for purposes approved by the publisher

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. It must be free from restrictions, so you can use it for both commercial and non commercial purposes.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. It must be free from restrictions, so you can use it for both commercial and non commercial purposes.

title: Third parties & contracts
body: The publication of open data may be required as part of the tendering, procurement and contracting lifecycle. If you require advice on open licensing and procurement, contact the Open Data Team at opendata@finance-ni.gov.uk

_items.title: Third parties
_items.body:
Governments often use contractors to provide services on their behalf.

The Northern Ireland civil service is committed to publishing open data about services, and extending that to third parties.

This publication is important because where public money is spent it should create a public good. Opening the data is an effective way to help deliver this and make it more transparent.

_items.title: Including open data in contracts
_items.body:
To ensure that data collected and used by contractors is also published as open data, an organisation can:

  • include this as a condition in the contract.

  • retain ownership of the data to publish it as open data themselves.

Take me to a guide on embedding open data into contracts

title: Culture change
body:
Adopting open data will often mean that an organisation needs to change the way it operates.

People driving initiatives need to spend time developing a shared vision, overcoming barriers and building coalitions for change.

_graphic.attribution: The Open Data Institute [CC-BY-SA]

title: Common barriers: Fearing data
body:
If data is unused and unloved, it will degrade and could potentially lead to security risks, reputational and brand damage. This scenario is known as ‘the wasteland’.

The wasteland is most prevalent in situations where unaddressed fears arising from legitimate concerns – such as who has access to data and how it might be used – prevent any benefits being realised.

Data might not be collected or used to the extent it could be. Individuals withdrawing consent could lead to data that is biased and misleading.

Putting in place practices that ensure the way data is collected and used is trustworthy can help to alleviate fears.

_items.title: Such practices include:
_items.body:
Building in ethical considerations to data collection, management and use.

Making data open so anyone can access, use and benefit from data.

Engaging widely with people and organisations who are affected.

title: What makes quality open data
body:
Assessing how usable open data is cannot be done quickly.

There are several community-based standards and quality marques that can help you assess how usable data is.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What makes data usable
  • How standards help increase the usability of data
  • Marques of quality

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]

title: Assessing open data quality - in two minutes
displayTitle: Assessing open data quality - in two minutes
body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains what quality data is, how to recognise it and which quality marques consumers of open data should look for.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: Q: What makes data usable?
body: What makes data usable?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Context to help a human understand it
Structure, so a machine can manipulate it
An endorsement from the publisher
How many people are already using it

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it.

title: Making data usable
body:
Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it.

Open data users need the permission of the data publisher, granted by an open licence. But the open licence alone is not enough to guarantee the usability of data.

There are many other aspects to consider that make data usable including:
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
In addition to the open licence, you must:

  • abide by data protection legislation.

  • preserve the rights of individuals, providers and third parties.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers should:

  • link to the data from their website.

  • update the data regularly if it changes.

  • commit to continue to make the data available.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three requirements that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • Publish the data in a widely used format

  • Make sure the data structure is simple and machine readable

  • Provide clear documentation to describe the structure, types and codes within the data, for example, abbreviations.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets are supported by:

  • active support channels.

  • discussion groups and forums.

  • published how-to guides on working with the data.

title: FAIR data principles
body:
The FAIR data principles, more widely used for research and scientific data, set out four basic principles that data should be Findable, Accessible, Interoperable and Reusable by others. 

Data becomes Findable when it is well described with clear metadata and referenced in many portals, publications and websites.

Data becomes Accessible when it can be easily downloaded or transferred. 

Data becomes Interoperable when it can be combined and remixed with other data, using shared terminology and standards.

Data becomes Reusable when it is made available under a licence that permits wide reuse and updated on a regular basis.

These categories are very similar to those of the ODI Open Data Certificates.

title: Evaluating the usability of data
body:
One of the main frustrations people have when trying to reuse data is the inconsistent ways in that data is represented. 

Take the following two datasets and compare them. 

What differences are you able to spot that mean the datasets are inconsistent with each other?

  1. Differences in date formats

  2. DIfferences in units on numbers

  3. Abbreviations vs= no abbreviations

  4. Different ways of representing locations, easting/northing v longitude/latitude

title: Evaluating the usability of data
body:
Using standards to increase the usability  of data

One key way to increase the usability of data is to conform to widely used standards. A standard is a documented and reusable agreement that details how something should be done.

Everyday standards include standards for electrical sockets so any appliance can be plugged in and standard measurements for drinks.

In data, there are a number of standards that already exist for everything from date formats (ISO 8601) to how to be compliant with General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) (ISO 27701).

title: The impact of standards for data
displayTitle: The impact of standards for data
body: Standards for data can have social, environmental and economic impact.

_items.title: Social impact
_items.body:
OpenActive is an initiative to get providers to publish data about when and where people can do physical activity and sports. OpenActive provides standards for the data to make it more comparable and usable, making it easier for organisations and businesses to find details of physical activities happening in their local area.


In England, the brownfield site open data standard was created to enable local planning authorities in England to share consistent and publicly available data on land suitable for residential development.

_items.title: Environmental impact
_items.body: Recycling can be very complicated. The open waste data standard aims to standardise the data councils publish about recycling to make it easier for individuals and businesses to do so.

_items.title: Economic impact
_items.body: Open Banking, the standard for creating, sharing and using banking data, is developed and maintained collaboratively and transparently. It provides a focus for the shared vision of improving people’s banking experience and making the banking industry more innovative and efficient.

title: Q: Our meeasures of success
body: Which of the following are some of the key success measures of the Open Data Strategy for Northern Ireland?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Sustained increase in open data and use cases on the portal
A wide variety of use cases
A culture of proactive publishing
300,000 datasets published on the portal
Increased numbers of freedom of information requests

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

In the Open Data Strategy for Northern Ireland, we list the following as our measures for success:

  • Sustained increase in open data on the portal

  • Wide variety of use cases

  • A culture of proactive publishing

  • Automated publication pipelines successfully used

  • Development of data validation tools to ensure better quality data

  • Raised awareness of open data’s potential.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

In the Open Data Strategy for Northern Ireland, we list the following as our measures for success:

  • Sustained increase in open data on the portal

  • Wide variety of use cases

  • A culture of proactive publishing

  • Automated publication pipelines successfully used

  • Development of data validation tools to ensure better quality data

  • Raised awareness of open data’s potential.

title: Q: Keeping on track
displayTitle: How do Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) help measure the success of an initiative?
body: KPIs can help to...
instruction: Select an option, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: the initiative stay on track
identify and communicate successes and areas to improve
be ‘open by default’
identify who needs a promotion

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

KPIs can help initiatives to stay on track as well as identifying and communicating what’s going well, and areas for improvement.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

KPIs can help initiatives to stay on track as well as identifying and communicating what’s going well, and areas for improvement.

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]

title: Measuring success for open data
body:
Successful open data initiatives do more than simply put data on the web. The most data-savvy organisations also put in place frameworks and policies to support and incentivise innovation. Open data communities need to be built and success stories communicated. Together, these will help more people understand the benefits of open data.

In this module we’ll explore:

  • Measuring success
  • Keeping on track
  • Our measures of success

title: Comparing open data initiatives - in two minutes
displayTitle: Comparing open data initiatives - in two minutes
body: ODI International Development Manager Liz Carolan explains key ways to measure the success of open data initiatives, what a demand-focused approach to open data is and how performance indicators add value to open data initiatives.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: Q: Success criteria
body: What criteria could you use to measure the success of an open data initiative?
instruction: Select an option, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Readiness to support open data initiatives
How many key datasets are already being published openly
What tangible benefits open data is already creating
Number of visits to the open data portal

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The three key criteria for comparing and measuring successful open data initiatives are:

  • The readiness to support and open data initiative

  • How many key datasets are already being published openly

  • The tangible benefits open data is already creating

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The three key criteria for comparing and measuring successful open data initiatives are:

  • The readiness to support and open data initiative

  • How many key datasets are already being published openly

  • The tangible benefits open data is already creating

title: Measuring success
body:
When evaluating the success of an open data initiative, it is important to look beyond the quantity of data published and focus on demand for the data.

The Open Data Barometer provides a global measure for comparing countries' progress. It uses three key indicators: readiness, implementation and impact.

While the Open Data Barometer has not been updated for a few years, its methodology is still the best in class for comparing countries’ progress on open data. As the methodology is open, anyone is able to replicate the research.
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Open data readiness
_items.body:
To what extent is an organisation or country ready to support an open data initiative?

The following are important indicators of readiness to support an open data initiative.

  • Open licences supported
  • Policies and procedures established
  • Investments made
  • Educational support available
  • Wider engagement undertaken

The Open Data Strategy for Northern Ireland and the National Action Plan are clear policies that demonstrate support and investment in our open data initiative.

_items.title: Open data implementation
_items.body:
Data is now as important to our national infrastructure as roads or internet access. For public bodies and governments, there are certain datasets that should be open as a way to support innovation, generate value and grow the economy.

The key datasets identified in the Open Data Barometer include:
  • Mapping and land ownership data
  • National statistics
  • Budget, government spending, international trade and public contracting data
  • Company registration data
  • Health, education, crime and environmental statistics
  • Election results
You can explore which key datasets Northern Ireland has published by searching by category on OpenDataNI.

In Northern Ireland, some property and land datasets are open, but unlike in the rest of the UK, land ownership remains held by the Land and Property Services.

_items.title: Open data impact
_items.body:
Without evidence of impact, communities are less likely to grow around the data and innovation can be less widespread. The following are important indicators of impact:

  • Increasing efficiency and transparency of government
  • Economic growth driven by open data
  • Social and environmental benefits

On OpenDataNI, you can explore the Showcase stories which highlight where our open data has already been used. One of the aims of the Open Data Strategy for Northern Ireland is to expand the number of stories available. These case studies are low risk and often quick and inexpensive, while providing life changing services for some.

title: Keeping on track
body: KPIs help keep open data initiatives on track.
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Managing progress
_items.body:
KPIs help to manage the process of open data initiatives.

KPIs should be set to measure open data readiness, implementation and impact.

_items.title: Communicate successes
_items.body: KPIs can help to communicate the progress and the success of your open data initiative. Promoting where you have had an impact, and how you have met your targets helps to demonstrate that you are delivering value with your initiative.

_items.title: Staying user-focused
_items.body:
The most successful open data initiatives focus on all Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) at the same time.

Successful initiatives focus on users first to build communities, educate and streamline supply so that even imperfect open data can get into the hands of users quickly, to maximise its value.

Number driven targets, such as publishing a certain amount of datasets, regardless of quality or demand from users, won’t necessarily help to make an impact.

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]

title: Why should we worry about sustainability?
displayTitle: Why should we worry about sustainability?
body:
Open data must be relevant, up-to-date and accessible in order to be useful.

A sustainable open data programme is one that continues to release data regularly with at least the same or improving quality and quantity.

In this module we'll explore:

  • How to make sense of sustainability
  • Why sustainability matters to you
  • What to look for in sustainable open datasets

title: Making open data sustainable – in two minutes
displayTitle: Making open data sustainable – in two minutes
body: ODI Startup Programme Manager Ulrich Atz explains the importance of sustainability for open data and why it matters to users. He also talks through some of the key indicators that an open data initiative is built to last.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: Why does sustainability matter?
body: Why should I be concerned about whether the open data I work with is sustainable?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Creates solid foundations
_items.body:
Sustainability is not just good for the users. The publisher also benefits from a sustainable open data programme by:

  • enhancing the trust of the community in the publisher’s organisation
  • supporting the creation of new products and services
  • simplifying the publishers' reuse of their own data

_items.title: Enhances trust
_items.body: Sustainable open data allows a large community to build and analyse data for their own purposes. Good sustainable open data can enhance the publisher’s reputation and also builds trust and interest in the data. Syngenta publishes yearly data on its good growth plan. While its intention was to build trust, there has been growing interest in using the data in other ways, for example to explore benchmarking efficiency across farms and regions.

_items.title: Builds business connections
_items.body: Sustained open data has the power to unlock new customer channels, enabling other businesses to build on a publisher's data. In many cases these businesses provide direct benefits back to the publisher, as is the case with Thomson Reuters. The company publishes identifiers openly, which reduces costs for them as well as helps them to manage large amounts of complex data, as well as increasing value for their customers.

_items.title: Improves data usability
_items.body:
One of the most frequent reusers of a publisher's data may well be the publisher. Why separate the public release of data from internal data usage?

Many benefits of TfL’s open data are clearly documented, but one benefit that is not often talked about is how open data helps TfL’s procurement processes.

As its data is already open, when TfL goes to trade shows, all potential products are already using the data in real time. This means that no time is wasted on data sharing agreements on the technical implementation of data, and instead, TfL can make quicker procurement decisions based on value for money and quality of service.

title: Q: What makes open data sustainable?
body: What factors help make an open dataset sustainable?
instruction: Choose three of the options below and select 'Submit'

_items.text: Secure funding
Large file size
Active support
Wide reuse
Restricting access to those who pay

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Secure funding, the active support of the publisher and wide reuse to generate value from the data all influence the sustainability of an open dataset.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?
Secure funding, the active support of the publisher and wide reuse to generate value from the data all influence the sustainability of an open dataset.

title: Q: Why does sustainability matter?
body: Sustainable open data...
instruction: Choose your answer and select 'Submit'

_items.text: encourages reuse of the data
is a tick box exercise
highlights the low quality of the data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Sustainable open data releases encourage reuse of the data, as users can be confident that the data will be updated. This in turn drives innovation and the creation of new businesses and services on the back of that data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Sustainable open data releases encourage reuse of the data, as users can be confident that the data will be updated. This in turn drives innovation and the creation of new businesses and services on the back of that data.

title: Q: What to look for when assessing sustainability?
displayTitle: What to look for when assessing sustainability?
body: What should you look for when assessing the sustainability of an open dataset?
instruction: Choose three of the options below and select 'Submit'
