_items.text: The data's publishing history
How much it costs
Who is already using  the data
What format the data is in
Who is funding the data's release

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Looking for the publishing history, who is using the data and how it is paid for are all key questions to ask when determining the sustainability of the dataset.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Looking for the publishing history, who is using the data and how it is paid for are all key questions to ask when determining the sustainability of the dataset.

title: Looking for clues
body: A sustainable release combines secure funding, active support and wide reuse. These traits are not always obvious when you first find a dataset. Ask yourself the following to help spot good sources:
instruction: Click the headings to learn more.

_items.title: What is the source?
_items.body:
Ask yourself who has released the data and how much confidence you have in their commitment to continue to update it.

One of the most important indicators of sustainability is how confident you feel about the organisation who collects it.

If the data is from the government, might an election or a change in priority affect its open release?

_items.title: What does the licence say?
_items.body:
Licences can also offer clues about data's sustainability.

When looking at a licence, ask yourself what the text might indicate about the dataset's future and the publisher's confidence in it? Does it contain a commitment to update it regularly?

Remember that without a licence, data is not truly open. The licence gives you certainty that data can be freely used and shared.

_items.title: Who is already using the data?
_items.body:
The more widely a dataset is used, the more pressure there is for it to be sustained.

Ask yourself who else is using this dataset and for what purposes.

Try to find out whether the dataset is used internally by the publisher.

Both aspects indicate whether the publisher cares about the dataset and is under external pressure not to remove access to it, or change it for their own purposes.

_items.title: What is the publishing history?
_items.body:
Assessing open data's sustainability ultimately depends on how much trust you place in its publisher.

Ask yourself how long the dataset has been published for. A long history of updates is a good sign, but beware external factors such as project length or term in office. A key indicator of a sustainable initiative is one that outlives these external factors.

_items.title: How can I contribute?
_items.body:
Using a dataset yourself will help drive its demand and influence its sustainability.

Think about joining any communities of practice that exist around the dataset.

Try to find out whether the publisher plays an active role in these communities and whether they act upon feedback to improve their services.

Ask yourself what value you can demonstrate that will enhance the sustainability that is ensured by the data publisher.

title: Making sense of sustainability in open data
displayTitle: Making sense of sustainability in open data
body: A sustainable open dataset is supported by:

_items.title: Secure funding for open data
_items.body:
Just because a dataset can be freely used does not mean there is no cost to collecting or releasing the data. Funding can be secured by:

  • Demonstrating the ongoing value of open data to the organisation
  • Gaining financial support from another source which supports open data publication

_items.title: Active support for open data
_items.body:
Making open data sustainable for an organisation usually requires senior-level backing to ensure it is prioritised, and the support of staff who are responsible for maintaining quality.

Active support is achieved when a company commits to maintaining open data as part of its daily operations.

_items.title: Wide reuse of open data
_items.body: Sustainable reuse is achieved when the services created with that data become critical to the success of the publisher’s business. The London transport system Transport for London’s datasets are used by millions when they access transport apps like Citymapper. These apps drive usage of TfL’s services and, as such, TfL has a commitment in its digital strategy to regularly update the data.

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]

title: Getting to grips with platforms
body:
A platform is a major piece of software on which smaller pieces of software and content can be run. For open data, the largest platform is the web. There are lots of other purpose-built software that can help you to publish open data, or provide interactive tools to help you to explore it.

Our platform is OpenDataNI. All government data should be published here. You might come across other open data platforms when searching for data.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What open data platforms are
  • Why open data platforms matter
  • Approaches to open data platform design
  • Open data platforms across Europe

title: Open data platforms – in two minutes
displayTitle: Open data platforms – in two minutes
body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains what open data platforms are, the different platforms available and the advantages of platforms for users.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: What is an open data platform?
body:
Open data platforms are pieces of software that make it simpler to publish and manage open data on the web.

For publishers, an open data platform provides a pathway to publish data. Platforms guide publishers through the process of publishing data, and offer users consistency and ease of access to open data from around the world.

Across government and the civil service in Northern Ireland, our open data platform is OpenDataNI. The OpenData NI platform is available for all NI public sector bodies to publish their data on at no cost.

title: Key features of open data platforms
displayTitle: Key features of open data platforms
body: Open data platforms make it easier for users to discover, access and use consistent open data.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.

_items.title: Discoverable data
_items.body:
Open data platforms promote open data to users. Platforms are designed to allow users to quickly find and reuse relevant open data.

Platforms are search-optimised to make it easier to find relevant resources. Platforms also provide data-feeds that can be discovered and indexed in systems across the Web.

These data feeds allow search engines like Enigma.io to index open data and make it easier to find.
Discover more at enigma.io

_items.title: Consistent user experience
_items.body:
There are a limited number of open data platforms, which means you don’t need to understand lots of different technologies to discover large amounts of open data.

Open data platforms are designed with the user in mind – their layout and design can make it easier to discover data.

For examples of sites using open data platforms, look at: data.gov.uk, data.gov.ie or for something further afield africaopendata.org

Note that many governments use a standard naming convention for the web address of the data platform, so a simple starting point for finding open data for a country is to enter data.gov.[country top-level domain].

_items.title: Consistent access to data
_items.body:
The development of open standards by the web community has led to consistent Application Programming Interfaces (APIs) for discovering, accessing and using data.

The limited number of open data platforms and consistent features of their user interfaces make it simple for people to use the different features while feeling comfortable with the software.

The platforms also have similar structures and formats for exposing metadata, as well as the data itself.

title: Q: What is an open data platform?
displayTitle: What is an open data platform?
body: An open data platform is...
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: a sales platform for businesses
a piece of software that helps get open data on the web
an internal data management tool

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

An open data platform is a piece of software that helps get open data on the web. It provides publishers a streamed process for publishing data and users a consistent way to access, use and share data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

An open data platform is a piece of software that helps get open data on the web. It provides publishers a streamed process for publishing data and users a consistent way to access, use and share data.

title: Q: What are the benefits of an open data platform?
displayTitle: What are the benefits of an open data platform?
body: Open data platforms help...
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: make it easier for users to access and use open data
ensure the data is high quality
ensure the data is documented correctly
keep the data consistent
make it easier for discover open data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The three main benefits of open data platforms are making it easier for users to discover, access and use open data and for publishers to keep the data consistent.

Although they can assist with establishing context and community, these aspects require additional effort from the publisher and remain two of the key challenges in open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The three main benefits of open data platforms are making it easier for users to discover, access and use open data and for publishers to keep the data consistent.

Although they can assist with establishing context and community, these aspects require additional effort from the publisher and remain two of the key challenges in open data.

title: Q: Approaches to open data platform design
displayTitle: Approaches to open data platform design
body: Take a look at these two data platforms. Open Bristol is a data management platform, whereas the USA’s open data portal is a data catalogue.

_items.text: Which is easier for monthly or yearly export reports?
Which is easier for continuous live data?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data catalogues, like the USA open data portal, are easier for monthly or yearly export reports. Data management platforms, such as Open Bristol, make it easier to publish continuous live data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Data catalogues, like the USA open data portal, are easier for monthly or yearly export reports. Data management platforms, such as Open Bristol, make it easier to publish continuous live data.

title: Approaches to open data platform design
displayTitle: Approaches to open data platform design
body: Platforms provide different approaches to publishing and exposing open data. Discover the different approaches below:

_items.title: Data catalogues
_items.body:
An open data catalogue is a platform that lists datasets on the web. Data catalogues are like directories. They know what open data exists, what it is about, where it is and how to get hold of it.

An open data catalogue links users to data that is located somewhere else on the web. They offer a consistent way of locating a diverse set of data that is widely scattered.

The CKAN platform, used by places like Amsterdam, Berlin and Copenhagen can be used as a data catalogue. Open Data NI also runs on CKAN.

_items.title: Data management
_items.body:
Open data management platforms can also play an active role in the way a publisher manages and maintains a dataset. Publishers can update data directly in the platform and regularly provide updates.

For users, searching for and manipulating open data without having to download it can make reusing it a lot easier.

For publishers however, there is a much greater challenge in structuring and formatting data for the platform. This can be overcome if the publisher also uses the publishing platform to access the data.

The Socrata platform, used by Bristol and the London Borough of Camden, and the Open Data Soft platform used by Leicester City are good examples of data management platforms.

_items.title: Comparison
_items.body:
Data catalogues provide:

  • Federated search across a wide domain.
  • Mechanisms for discovery.
  • Key metadata relating to licence and how up to date the data is.

Data management platforms provide:

  • Authoritative sources for data.
  • Increased data quality.
  • The ability to search and manipulate data directly.

The distinctions between data management platforms and data catalogues can also vary between providers. Take me to comparative analysis of data platforms.

title: Choosing the right format for open data
displayTitle: Choosing the right format for open data
body:
The format of an open dataset refers to the way in which the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right format helps ensure the data can be simply managed and reused. To maximise reuse of data, it may be necessary for a publisher to use a number of structures and formats available across different platforms to suit users' needs.

In this module we'll explore:

  • Why the structure and format matters
  • Tabular data structures and formats
  • Machine readable tabular data
  • Other data structures and formats

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]

title: Q: Why is picking the right format for open data important?
displayTitle: Why is picking the right format for open data important?
body: Why is picking the right structure and format for open data important?
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Ensure that privacy is protected
Drive down costs
Ease, usability, management and access

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Picking the correct formats will assist usability, make management easier and lower the barriers of access. Choices here will not affect privacy and may even increase cost

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Picking the correct formats will assist usability, make management easier and lower the barriers of access. Choices here will not affect privacy and may even increase cost.

title: Choosing the right format for open data
displayTitle: Choosing the right format for open data
body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Choosing the right structure and format makes it as easy as possible to access, use and share the data.

For data to be as accessible as possible, it must be in a format that

  • The (human) user can understand
  • Machines can read
  • Supports the data's easy reuse.
  • Doesn’t require proprietary tools like Microsoft Excel or Adobe Creative Cloud (Photoshop etc) to access.

The format appropriate for each dataset may be different. A document (like a PDF) may make the data easy for a human to understand but not the most readable for a machine. For this reason, it might be necessary to make the data available in a range of different formats to meet the needs of the data, the human users and the machines.

title: Tabular data
body:
The most common structure for open data is tabular. Data is organised into rows and columns listing sequential values, such as expenditure.

If the data is based on separate entries that are not linked to each other then a tabular file structure in a format such as CSV is ideal. CSV stands for comma separated value, and it is simply lines of data with each data point separated from the next by a comma. 

While it doesn’t maintain formatting and graphs like Microsoft Excel, CSV is an open and machine readable format.

An example of appropriate tabular data is OpenDataNI’s GP Prescribing Data.

title: Other data structures and formats
body: Although tabular data in a CSV format is the most common structure for government open data, there are other structures and formats that you may come across.
instruction: Click the headings to explore further

_items.title: Hierarchical data
_items.body: Hierarchical data shows the relationships between data points, such as a family tree or municipalities in each country. If the dataset depends on the relationship between data points and follows a structure in which data points are linked in vertical ‘trees’, a format such as JSON is ideal.

_items.title: Network data
_items.body:
Network structured data allows relationships to exist between any combination of elements in any direction.

A good example of a network data structure is a social network. Think of your network of friends and their friends on Facebook; consider first, second and third degree contacts on LinkedIn.

The Web is another example of a network data structure, where web pages link to any number of other pages in any direction.

_items.title: Live data and data feeds
_items.body:
Some data is not suitable to be made available as a downloadable file. Much of this data is updated so regularly that the file downloads would be too large for most users. This type of open data structure may be made available by a machine interface, also known as an application programming interface (API).

There are many services that make machine interfaces available over the web. These services can be directly integrated into other Web applications. For an example of an open data API, see the Irish Rail API.

_items.title: Geospatial data
_items.body:
Geospatial data is often more complex than simple tabular datasets.

It can exist as a hierarchical dataset, detailing countries and counties/states, or as a network dataset, detailing roads. It can also be unstructured data too.

When publishing this type of data, you could consider formats like geoJSON, shapefile and KML. These formats are specifically designed with usability in mind and can easily be imported and exported from specialist mapping tools like Open Street Map and CartoDB.

If you need to publish geospatial data and you don’t know what format to choose, you can contact the Open Data NI team at opendata@finance-ni.gov.uk

_items.title: Unstructured data
_items.body: Some data is unstructured, such as video files, images or sound files. The best format for publishing that type of data is usually the one in which it was built or managed. If it is a reusable, or open format, that’s even better.

title: Open data formats
body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant explains why formats matter in open data, how to choose the right structure and formats, and why CSV is a good starting point for most tabular open data.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: Q: The first 3 Stars
body:
The first star is all about ensuring anyone is free to access, use and share the data, regardless of format.

The first star requires:
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: The data to be openly licensed
The data to downloadable from the web
The data to be available on request

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

The first star requires an open licence.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

The first star requires an open licence.

title: The first 3 Stars
body: To make the data two stars:
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Publish the data in the original format, for example a Microsoft Excel workbook with graphs, charts and formula
Publish the data in PDF format
Publish the data via an API

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

To make data two stars, it should be published in the original, reusable format AND have an open licence.

To make data three stars, it should be published in a format like CSV which is open and reusable, as well as having an open licence.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

To make data two stars, it should be published in the original, reusable format AND have an open licence.

To make data three stars, it should be published in a format like CSV which is open and reusable, as well as having an open licence.

title: The first 3 Stars
body: To make the data three stars:
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: Embed the data in a web page e.g. a table on a website
Publish the data in format such as CSV
Publish the data in PDF format

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

To make data three stars, it should be published in a format like CSV which is open and reusable, as well as having an open licence.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

To make data three stars, it should be published in a format like CSV which is open and reusable, as well as having an open licence.

title: Stars 2 and 3
body:
The second and third stars are about usability and more about the technical format of the data. The second star is about ensuring humans can access, use and reuse the data, while the third star is about machines being able to do the same. 

See if you can match the following.

_graphic.attribution: Open Data NI [All rights reserved]

title: How to clean your data
body:
One of the biggest challenges when working with any data is dealing with errors. Often errors are not even noticed by data publishers because the data can change over many years. In other cases, errors can be the result of human mistakes in data entry, like mistyping or incorrect abbreviations.

When working with any data, it is important to know how to find errors and correct them to make the data more useful.

In this module we'll explore the following:

  • Common data errors
  • Useful data cleaning tools
  • Reasons for cleaning data

title: Revealing the value: what do we mean by clean data?
displayTitle: Revealing the value: what do we mean by clean data?
body:
Knowing that data is clean is important to ensure you have a reliable starting point when working with it and creating new value from it.

Clean data is data that is consistent, free from duplication and ready for machine consumption.

If data is clean, it is easier to combine it with different datasets and gain deeper insights.

title: Q: Why does data need to be cleaned?
displayTitle: Why does data need to be cleaned?
body: Uncleaned open data is a problem because:
instruction: Choose your answer, then click 'Submit'

_items.text: it cannot be plotted on a chart
imperfect data should not be published
anything derived from the data won’t be completely accurate

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Unclean data is a problem because anything derived from the data won’t be as accurate or effective. This should not prevent the publication or use of the data, but it needs to be cleaned first.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Unclean data is a problem because anything derived from the data won’t be as accurate or effective. This should not prevent the publication or use of the data, but it needs to be cleaned first.

title: What are the benefits of cleaning data?
displayTitle: What are the benefits of cleaning data?
body:
Data can lead to huge benefits for governments, the economy and people. However, if the data isn’t clean, analysis, insights or products derived from that data won’t be as effective. To realise the benefits of data, it needs to be up to date and correct.

A recent study found that the process of preparing data for analysis can take anywhere between 60% and 80% of the time of a data-driven project.

_items.title: Enhance usability
_items.body:
Sharing a clean open dataset will make the data more usable. Tools like Open Refine allow you to share change history, letting people know what has been cleaned and how. Making the process open as well as the data adds to the sustainability and trust a user can put in a dataset.

There are also data-cleaning communities emerging that could be supported more actively, such as OpenStreetMap communities.

_items.title: Discover insights
_items.body:
Many data-cleaning tools help you to combine and enrich datasets. This can lead to valuable insights being discovered.

For example, enriching a dataset that refers to businesses (by name or some other identifier) can inform you if the business is still trading and its current financial position.

title: Q: What are common errors in data?
displayTitle: What are common errors in data?
body: Which of the following are errors in data that require cleaning?
instruction: Choose three answers and click 'Submit'

_items.text: Mixed numerical scales
Lack of granularity
Redundant data
Lack of licence
Multiple representations

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in unclean data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in unclean data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean

title: Common errors in data
body: There are a number of common errors in data that you should look out for in any dataset you are working with.

_items.title: Wrong date formats
_items.body:
Dates can be written in inconsistent ways. Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes less obvious:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

Another challenge is that some applications, like Microsoft Excel, will ‘guess’ the format when a dataset is opened, which can hide how dates are actually written in the file.
The most common error is the mixed use of American (MM/DD/YYYY) and European (DD/MM/YYYY) formats.

_items.title: Multiple representation
_items.body:
People often try to save time when entering data by abbreviating terms. If these abbreviations are not consistent, they can cause errors in the dataset.

Differences in capitalisation, spacing and genders of adjectives can all cause errors.

_items.title: Duplicate records
_items.body: A duplicate record is where the same piece of data has been entered more than once. Duplicate records often occur when datasets have been combined or because it was not known there was already an entry.

_items.title: Redundant data
_items.body:
Redundant data is anything that is not relevant to your work with the dataset. Often a dataset has been created for a specific purpose which requires details you may not need.

Common occurrences of redundant data include rows that represent total amounts.

Other times columns of data have been combined or replicated in order to assist human readability.

_items.title: Mixed numerical scales
_items.body: Numerical values in datasets often use different scales to make it easier for a human to read. In budget datasets, for example, the units are often in the millions. 1,200,000 often becomes 1.2m. However, smaller amounts like 800,000 are still written in full. For a machine, this means they read the larger figure as 1.2, which causes errors.

_items.title: Mixed ranges
_items.body: Data is sometimes measured in ranges, such as age or salary range. In order for a machine to understand these ranges it is important to separate the high and low values.

_items.title: Spelling errors
_items.body:
Spelling errors are often difficult to identify in tabular data.

Don’t forget to run your data through a spell-checker to catch spelling errors.

title: The data-cleaning toolkit
body: Without clean data, we can’t build information. There are several useful tools that can help the process of cleaning data.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more

_items.title: The data-cleaning toolkit
_items.body:
When you are looking for errors in data, it may be necessary to download and upload datasets in many tools for cleaning and processing.

It is also important to keep a note of what changes have been made and share these openly with others so that everyone can benefit from your work, particularly if the data you are cleaning is existing open data that has been published.

In this section we look at two of the main tools and their uses:

  • Open Refine
  • Microsoft Excel and similar spreadsheet programmes

_items.title: Open Refine
_items.body:
Open Refine is a software tool designed to deal with uncleaned data. The tool is a column-based browser that allows you to fix errors across an entire open dataset in a single action. The errors that can be fixed include:

  • Date formats
  • Multiple representations
  • Duplicate records
  • Redundant data
  • Mixed numerical scales
  • Mixed ranges

_items.title: Spreadsheet programmes
_items.body:
Open Refine is a key tool for cleaning data. However, it is sometimes easier to fix some errors in a spreadsheet programme:

  • Spelling errors
  • Redundant data
  • Numerical verification
  • Fixing shifted data

title: Assessing data usability – in two minutes
displayTitle: Assessing data usability – in two minutes
body: ODI Trainer David Tarrant introduces the 5 Star Linked Open Data system as an assessment tool and helps you understand how and where it can be used.
instruction: To turn subtitles on and off, click the 'cc' button at the bottom right of the video

title: Unlocking the usability of open data
displayTitle: Unlocking the usability of open data
body: Each star gained represents an improvement in the usability of a dataset. Use the following simple checks to evaluate how many stars any dataset has.
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: 1 star - Checking the licence
_items.body:
Finding the licence for an open dataset can be one of the hardest steps.

An open licence is an explicit permission to use the data for both commercial and non-commercial purposes.=

If the licence isn’t obvious, try looking:

  • At the metadata record about the data

  • In the terms and conditions of the web page or site

  • Click on the data file, there might be a popup

  • Inside the data file itself

Websites feature licensing information in different ways, you may have to search a little on each site to find them.

_items.title: 2 star - Checking usability
_items.body:
When you discover open data on the web, there are several ways in which you can assess how usable it is. 

Ask yourself:

  • Do I think that this is the most user-friendly format in which to publish this particular data?

  • Does the file appear to be the same as the one the publisher uses?

  • Is there any other information that has been added by a human?

_items.title: 3 star - Checking openness
_items.body:
Open formats are sometimes difficult to assess. 

The following questions will help you understand if the data is available in an open format:

  • Can I open the file in more than one programme on my computer and still see the full functionality of the file?

  • When I look up the file format (for example CSV) online, does it say I need to download a specific programme to open it?

CSV is the most popular open format and is easy to identify. CSV qualifies for 3 stars as long as the other 2 are achieved. The UK open data portal provides some good examples of 3-star CSV datasets that are clearly marked with both a licence and file format.

Many open data portals are also publishing Open Document Format (ODF) files. These files may appear perfect for open data, however it can be difficult to identify the tool that can open these files.

body: Take a look at this dataset from the Food and Agriculture Organisation of the UN. According to the 5 Star Linked Open Data system, how many stars does this dataset achieve?

This data has no stars. Even though it is available in a reusable and open format, as the licence is not open (CC-BY-NC), it doesn’t achieve the first star. Each star must be awarded sequentially and none can be skipped.

title: Other data structures
body:
Not all data is suited to a tabular structure. There are two other key structures to be aware of: hierarchical and network.

Which example of data is best suited to which structure?

_items.text: Hierarchical data
Network data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Hierarchical data shows the vertical relationship between data. As such, a family tree is best shown in a hierarchical structure.

Network structured data allows any number of relationships between data, such as your LinkedIn connections.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Hierarchical data shows the vertical relationship between data. As such, a family tree is best shown in a hierarchical structure.

Network structured data allows any number of relationships between data, such as your LinkedIn connections.

title: Machine readable tabular data
body:
For data to be usable, a human must be able to understand it and a machine be able to read it. We can program machines to be able to read many sorts of data, but there are some simple things we can do to make it easier.

Look at this picture of tabular data. How could you make it more machine readable? Use what you find to answer the questions below.
